H0.text: Land scarred by forest fires is the event most likely to result in change on a global scale among the variety of ecosystem‑disrupting events that can be local or larger in area.

H1.text: Erosion of ocean shorelines is the event most likely to result in changes on a global scale among the variety of ecosystem‑disrupting events, some of which cause local disturbances while others affect much larger areas.

H2.text: Converging plate boundaries are the event most likely to cause global‑scale changes among events that can disrupt ecosystems, ranging from local disturbances to larger‑area impacts.

H3.text: Destruction of tropical rain forests is the event most likely to result in changes on a global scale among the variety of ecosystem-disrupting events, some causing local disturbances and others affecting larger areas.

A4.text: Some of the deadliest natural disasters have occurred due to convergent boundary processes.

A5.text: Convergent boundaries occur between oceanic-oceanic lithosphere, oceanic-continental lithosphere, and continental-continental lithosphere.
